Intro to Religious Studies, Winter 2018

This is the webpage for Connie Kassor's RLST 100 course (Winter '18). Here is where you'll find readings, documents, and all information relevant to the course. If you want to find Connie outside of class, she's in Main Hall 411, and her office hours are Mondays 11am-Noon.

contact

  • Main Hall 411
  • Office Hours: Mondays 11am-noon
  • or by appointment
  • or just drop by -- really.

2018 © Intro to Religious Studies, Winter 2018

Schedule at a Glance

RLST 100 - Schedule of Readings and Assignments

Week 1

Wednesday, January 3

  • Henderson, “Open Letter to the Kansas School Board”

Friday, January 5

  • Sullivan, “Neutralizing Religion, or What is the Opposite of ‘Faith-Based’?”
  • Read the syllabus. Seriously. Read the whole thing all the way through. Carefully.

Week 2

Monday, January 8

  • Gunkel and Westermann, Genesis, Introductions

Wednesday, January 10

  • Westermann, Genesis, chapters 1-4
  • Lacey, Word on the Street, chapters 1-3

Friday, January 12

  • Crumb, Illustrated Genesis, Chapters 1-4

Week 3

Monday, January 15 No class

Wednesday, January 17

  • Schopen, “Archaeology and Protestant Presuppositions in the Study of Indian Buddhism”

Friday, January 19

  • No new reading (Visit to Wriston in class)

Week 4

Monday, January 22

  • Jutla, “The Evolution of the Golden Temple of Amritsar into a Major Sikh Pilgrimage Center”

Wednesday, January 24

  • McLeod, “Sikh Hymns to the Divine Name,” and “The Order for Khalsa Initiation”

Friday, January 26

  • No reading (image presentations in class)

Week 5

Monday, January 29

  • Ramanujan, “Three Hundred Ramayanas: Five Examples and Three Thoughts on Translation”

Wednesday, January 31

  • Flueckiger, “Literacy and the Changing Concept of Text: Women’s Ramayana Mandali in Central India”

Friday, February 2

  • The Ramayana (summary)
  • Valmiki’s Ramayana
    • Note: You do not have to read this, but please look at it, to get a sense of how massive this text is!
  • Chopra, Ramayan Reloaded

Week 6

Monday, February 5

  • Smith, “Religion, Religions, Religious”

Wednesday, February 7 Midterm Exam

Friday, February 9 No class

Week 7

Monday, February 12

  • Khyentse, “What Makes You a Buddhist?”

Wednesday, February 14

  • Dowman, “How Drukpa Kunley Bound the Demons of Bhutan”

Friday, February 16

  • Film TBD
    • We will arrange a screening on Wed or Thu evening, and if you can’t make it, the film will be on reserve in the library.

Week 8

Monday, February 19

  • Satlow, “Defining Judaism: Accounting for ‘Religions’ in the Study of Religion”

Wednesday, February 21

  • Jospe, “Covenant and Chosenness”
  • Chabon, “Chosen, but not Special”
  • Gitlin and Leibovitz, “The Centrality of Jewish Chosenness”

Friday, February 23

  • No new reading (time to work on group presentations)

Week 9

Monday, February 26

  • Streett, “Snake Handling and Mark 16:18: Primitive Christianity or Indigenous American Religion?”

Wednesday, February 28

  • No reading (group presentations in class)

Friday, March 2

  • Metraux, “Religious Terrorism in Japan: The Fatal Appeal of Aum Shinrikyo”
  • Marshall, “Why is the Aum Cult Thriving?”

Week 10

Monday, March 5

  • Jain, “Is Downward Dog the Path to Hell?” and “Claiming Yoga for India

Wednesday, March 7

  • King, “Seeing Spirituality in Chimpanzees”

Friday, March 9

  • No new reading, but come to class with your notes from the term. We’ll spend time reviewing what we’ve covered this term, in preparation for the final exam.
